title: Loughrigg Fell Walk Route

images.title: Michael Graham / Loughrigg Fell
images.caption: The fell From the path to The How. Junipers on Lad Crag in shot

images.title: Chris Heaton / Path descending off Loughrigg Fell
images.caption: Path descending off the fell. This footpath is somewhat juicy, having been adopted by a small stream as the best way of descending towards the River Rothay in the valley below. We were walking between Loughrigg Tarn and Rydal.

images.title: Nigel Davies / Ewe Crag on the north edge of Loughrigg Fell
images.caption: Ewe Crag on the north edge of Loughrigg Fell. This is the view southwest from the bridle path between Rydal Water and Grasmere

images.title: Looking into Langdale from Loughrigg Fell by Karl and Ali, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking into Langdale from the fell.

images.title: David Brown / Loughrigg Fell summit
images.caption: A couple relax on the summit.

images.title: Small Tarn on Loughrigg Fell by Dave Green, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Small Tarn on the fell.

description: The climb to Loughrigg fell from Grasmere is a very popular one. It's a reasonably straightforward climb with wonderful views over Rydal Water and Grasmere Lake. The walk starts in the centre of Grasmere and follows country lanes and good footpaths to the 335 m (1,099 ft) summit. You start by following Red Bank road from Grasmere which runs around the western side of the lake before picking up a footpath to the summit which is effectivley a series of stone steps. The route also passes Loughrigg Terrace which is well worth a short detour. This level path affords wonderful views towards Helm Crag and the Fairfield group and leads to the fascinating Loughrigg Caves. From the Loughrigg Fell summit there are lovely views of Elterwater, Langdale, the Coniston Fells and Windermere. You will also find an Ordnance Survey triangulation column beside a large cairn. The fell is on the Windermere Way circular walk, so you can pick this up to extend your walk. You could also descend the hill to the south and visit the tranquil Loughrigg Tarn and continue to Elterwater where you can enjoy a waterside stroll along the River Brathay and visit Skelwith Force waterfall.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Just to the north there's the climb to Silver How from Grasmere. The walk also visits the National Trust owned Allan Bank, the former home of William Wordsworth. For more walking ideas in the area see the Lake District Walks page.

display_address: Church Parking, Red Bank Road, Town End, Lakes, Grasmere, Westmorland and Furness, England, LA22 9SW, United Kingdom
